title: Andrew Mims of Oak Grove: Leading with Compassion to Redefine Family Planning
description: He founded Oak Grove Estate Planning to address a system that has felt impersonal and confusing for many individuals and families.
content:
Entrepreneurs arrive at their work from many different places. Some chase scale and returns, some follow a lifelong blueprint, and others are driven by a conviction to fix a problem they’ve watched hurt people. For Andrew B. Mims, the motivation to build a business began in that last category. He founded Oak Grove Estate Planning to address a system that has felt impersonal and confusing for many individuals and families.

This motivation was shaped during the early stages of Mims’ legal life. Fresh out of law school, he spent time at the bench, clerking for a judge and sitting at the periphery of family pain. “Those moments in the courtroom left an impression on me. I always thought of the disputes that started from ambiguous documents, last-minute handwritten wills that became the seeds of litigation, and family relationships ripped apart by preventable uncertainty,” he shares. “Those scenes change what you believe the law should be for. Less an instrument of posthumous contest and more a tool for preserving dignity and continuity.”

That emotional catalyst didn’t just inspire a career shift. It tapped into legacy. Entrepreneurship was already familiar in Mims’ family. He grew up around people who started and ran businesses, and he’s married to a person with that same restless initiative. His decision to start his firm was further inspired by compassion. “Caring for a family member with lifelong support needs taught me how fragile plans can be for families who must think long-term and adapt constantly,” Mims recalls.

The seasoned attorney then built Oak Grove to make estate planning accessible, thoughtful, and resilient for families. He realized that too many practices treat estate planning like a checklist item. Draft the document, collect the fee, and move on. “Plans must adapt, because life does. Relationships evolve, careers twist and turn, children enter the picture, and health journeys unfold. Each moment rewrites what once seemed certain,” Mims remarks.

Oak Grove’s approach centers on ongoing relationships. It offers regular reviews, proactive conversations, and a posture of availability so that plans remain in step with clients’ lives. He drew on his consulting experience in larger firms to shape Oak Grove’s systems and client journey. By keeping what worked and discarding what didn’t, he delivers both technical competence and a humane experience.

Mims also advocates for estate planning as a tool for all, not just the wealthy. At Oak Grove, he demystifies legal complexities and prioritizes accessible, relationship-driven service. Whether it’s new parents, blended families, business owners, or caregivers, he makes estate planning feel relevant, attainable, and personal.

The attorney stands out for his leadership style that responds to a weakness he sees in the field: lawyers stretched across too many practice areas, trying to be everything to everyone. Rather than wearing every hat, he chooses to focus. That specialization enables his team to delve into the technical nuances of estate planning while also mastering the softer skills of listening and translating legalese into workable plans.

“My energy goes into building relationships with allied professionals, like financial advisors and tax specialists, so clients can receive holistic advice without having to navigate a bewildering array of siloed experts,” Mims says. He runs the firm with an emphasis on clarity, operational rigor, and a calm client experience. The office was designed to put people at ease, to encourage conversations they may have avoided, and to remove the intimidation sometimes associated with legal planning.

Overall, Andrew Mims’s story isn’t only about legal mechanics. It’s about moral clarity. He saw the worst outcomes and decided to build a practice that prevents them. He combined professional skill with personal conviction to create Oak Grove, a firm that stands for prevention, clarity, and dignity.
